full_text:
Case 1:20-cr-00330-PAE Document 773 Filed 08/10/22 Page 25 of 29 3142 LCRVMAXT

1 MS. MENNINGER: Your Honor, at this point, because it
2 has only been three days, we believe that any suggestion that
3 they should stay later is beginning to sound like urging them
4 to hurry up, when clearly they know that they can deliberate as
5 long as they want and they should be able to deliberate as long
6 as they want. They haven't expressed any hesitation. They've
7 been asking for transcripts, they've been asking for materials.
8 While we would not mind the Court giving an instruction much like it did last week, telling the jurors that
9 should they choose to stay later on any given day, the Court
10 can make arrangements for them to do so, we would object to
11 trying to urge them to stay later if they are not asking to do
12 so and aren't expressing any difficulty in proceeding with the
13 deliberations that they are currently undertaking.
14
15 MS. MOE: Your Honor, the Court has previously extended certain days or contracted certain days, depending on
16 our schedule; and, in fact, I think the first day of
17 deliberations we had an extended day on the consent of both
18 parties. We don't believe that sends any kind of signal, other
19 than that the Court is setting a schedule. And we think that's
20 appropriate here given the circumstances.
21
22 THE COURT: I think what we should do, I'll tell them
23 that if deliberations are not complete starting tomorrow, I
24 would like you to make yourselves available to deliberate until
25 at least 6 p.m. each day. Of course, if you all agree to

SOUTHERN DISTRICT REPORTERS, P.C. (212) 805-0300
DOJ-OGR-00017329
